occurrences.line_text: Others lay shaded from the scorching heat;
In that same shadie couert, whereas lay
A little boate lay houing her before,
Of his strong foe, lay tombled in the myre,
Vnto her sonne, that lay in feeble state;
Whose trampling feet vpon the hollow lay
That each awhile lay like a sencelesse corse.
What fortune and his fate on him will lay,
Lay hid: thereof she countlesse summes did reare,
As if they lay in wait, or else themselues did hide.
And comming him before, low louted on the lay.
Yet stoupt he not, but lay still in the wind,
The silly man that in the thicket lay
Whereas his louely wife emongst them lay,
By which there lay a knight all wallowed
A lay of loues delight, with sweet consent:
And nicely trode, as thornes lay in his way,
His feeble steps, which shrunke, when hard theron he lay.
Who rolled on an heape lay still in swound,
Vpon the ground a while in slomber lay;
Strooke him so hugely, that in swowne he lay,
Out of the swowne, in which too long he lay;
His weapons, which lay scattered all abrode,
Of many swords, that lode on him did lay.
There as he lay, his wound he soone forgot,
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
And then lay musing long, on that him ill apayd.
So long he muzed, and so long he lay,
Where fearelesse I to sleepe me downe did lay.
And with meeke seruice and much suit did lay
There where through weary trauel she lay sleeping sou[n]d.
Yet will not he the louely spoile downe lay,
Lay hid in horrour of eternall night?
Who lay the whiles in swoune, full sadly set,
Weening therein some holy Hermit lay,
Of bitter thoughts, which deepe therein infixed lay.
Shee sitting by him as on ground he lay,
And thereof made a lamentable lay,
The euill case in which those Ladies lay;
Vnto the earth, and lay long while in senselesse swowne.
To view the thrals, which there in bondage lay:
And lay on load, as they him downe would beare;
With all my might I gan to lay about:
With many moe lay in ambushment there,
And all about her altar scattered lay
Vpon a recluse Virgin to lay hold,
Yet to lay hand on her, not one of all them daring.
Old Styx the Grandame of the Gods, doth lay.
In which his wretched loue lay day and night,
That loue it was, which in his hart lay vnreuealed.
If ought lay hidden in his grieued thought,
At length found out, whereas she hidden lay
But all the wrongs that he therein could lay,
Yet all the wrongs could not a litle right downe lay.
His battred ballances in peeces lay,
But when at them he with his flaile gan lay,
And thrise did lay his hand vpon his sword,
Vnder my foote let each lay downe his sword,
But that the sea it to my share did lay?
Meaning on him their cruell hands to lay,
And lay on heauen the guilt of their owne crimes.
From deathes dore, at which he lately lay,
She mote reuenge that blot, which on her lay.
So did Sir Artegall vpon her lay,
But when they thought on Talus hands to lay,
But if in his owne powre occasion lay,
And lay vpon him, for his greater dread,
He started vp, there where on ground he lay,
But soone as he began to lay about
That here and there like scattred sheepe they lay.
With that the Crocodile, which sleeping lay
So thereuppon long while she musing lay,
But first the Tygre clawes thereon did lay;
To lay his spoiles before his lemans traine:
Like one of those two Knights, which dead there lay.
Forth of her window as she looking lay,
Onely his shield and armour, which there lay,
And roiall pompe, which there long hidden lay,
A straunge aduenture, which not farre thence lay;
Gan forth to lay his bayte her to beguyle,
Charmes to the birds full many a pleasant lay,
How he his nets doth for their ruine lay:
An huge great Lyon lay, that mote appall
And all her traynes, and all her treasons forth did lay.
Right in the middest of the threshold lay,
The Monster vnderneath the Altar lay;
With his huge flaile began to lay about;
That they lay scattred ouer all the land,
About him flockt, and hard at him did lay;
Whiles yet his foe lay fast in sencelesse sound,
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
That armed knight, that low on ground he lay;
And him vnarm'd, as now he lay on ground,
Therefore faire Lady lay aside this griefe,
Through the thicke clouds, in which they steeped lay
Vprear'd her from the ground whereon she lay,
Tho on his shield he griple hold did lay,
Compeld him soone the spoyle adowne to lay.
Which lay thereby (so fortune him did ayde)
And euery part, that vnder sweathbands lay,
There she long groueling, and deepe groning lay,
And streight his combrous armes aside did lay
By which a little Hermitage there lay,
And therewithall rude hand on him did lay.
But ioyning close, huge lode at him did lay:
Where still he bathed lay in his owne bloody gore.
Lay in the lap of death, rewing his wretched bale.
Whereas the Prince himselfe lay all alone,
The whyles his Lord in siluer slomber lay,
But as he lay vpon the humbled gras,
Where still he lay, ne out of swoune awooke,
Abide, and from them lay your loathly hands;
Came running in, and whilest on ground he lay,
There whilest in Morpheus bosome safe she lay,
Now drowned in the depth of sleepe all fearelesse lay.
But all bootes not: they hands vpon her lay;
And when I wearie am, I downe doe lay
Nor draw vnto the lure of his lewd lay,
That who so hardie hand on her doth lay,
There lay she couered with confused preasse
Lay sleeping soundly in the bushes shade,
Gan all vpon him lay: there gan a dreadfull fight.
She forth gan lay vnto the open light
Both slaine in battell vpon Layburne plaine,
The warlike youthes on dayntie couches layd,
There also was that mightie Monarch layd
Againe he askt, where that same knight was layd,
From loftie steed, and downe to sleepe me layd;
The grace of God he layd vp still in store,
Much more then that, why they in bands were layd,
And three mens strength vnto the stroke he layd;
For she had layd her mournefull stole aside,
But they him layd full low in dungeon deepe,
Layd first his filthy hands on virgin cleene,
And slyding soft, as downe to sleepe her layd,
Me leading, in a secret corner layd,
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
On a sweet bed of lillies softly layd,
Or lips he layd on thing, that likt him best,
Is layd, they fiercely then begin to shoure,
From his fierce warres, and hauing from him layd
Next him was noble Elfinan, who layd
Vpon him fell, and lode vpon him layd;
In sumptuous bed she made him to be layd,
There she had him now layd a slombering,
Vpon a bed of Roses she was layd,
That speare enchaunted was, which layd thee on the greene.
Ne did she stay, till three on ground she layd,
And by her side her selfe she softly layd,
And with her flaming sword about her layd,
Yet sith they warlike armes haue layd away:
Of the sicke virgin, that her downe she layd
Did let him forage. Downe himselfe he layd
And load vpon him layd, his life for to haue had.
To commun accidents still open layd,
Thither they brought that wounded Squire, and layd
Whiles dayly plaisters to his wound she layd,
Vpon the grassie ground her selfe she layd
Vnto their maister, who in bed was layd,
Were ouerthrowne and layd on th'earth full cold,
His secret drift, till he her layd abord.
Was drawne forth, and in siluer basin layd,
And with his brondiron round about him layd;
But layd aside, when so she vsd her looser sport.
But in his armour layd him downe to rest:
To rest he layd him downe vpon the flore,
Her feeble ioynts layd eke a downe to rest;
And oft in wrath he layd him downe againe.
Then did he take that chaced Squire, and layd
And layd at them so sharpely and so sore,
To whom those rolles, layd vp in heauen aboue,
But to his bed was brought, and layd aboue,
In which his life vnluckily was layd,
That on the ground he layd him like a sencelesse blocke.
And layd on load with his huge yron flaile,
Yet the least word that euer could be layd
He did so first; and then the false he layd
So each of them layd downe his sword out of his hand.
Your brothers land the which the sea hath layd
With huge redoubled strokes she on him layd;
Where being layd, the wrothfull Britonesse
In which her wretched loue was captiue layd:
What were those knights, which there on grou[n]d were layd,
I layd aside, and haue of late forbore,
But still the tyrant sternely at him layd,
With that he fiercely at him flew, and layd
So off he did his shield, and downeward layd
And layd her vnderneath a bush to sleepe,
To seeke, if he perchance a sleepe were layd,
Who it perceiuing, hand vpon him layd,
And on them layd so huge and horribly,
And layd at him amaine with all his will and might.
With which he layd about, and made them fast to flie.
As to his Lord, and downe his weapons layd,
He there in shade himselfe had layd to rest,
Whom when as Turpin saw so loosely layd,
And his left hand vpon his collar layd.
Till heauy hand the Carle vpon him layd,
Sometimes aloft he layd, sometimes alow;
The which the God of loue hath on me layd,
Vpon the grasse her selfe adowne she layd;
Which by the Faery Queene was on him layd,
Who being now in dreadfull darknesse layd,
He at the length was slaine, and layd on ground,
Seeme much more louely in that darknesse layd,
She in the open fields had loosely layd
Rent vp her brest, and bosome open layd,
Full fiercely layde the Amazon about,
But at her feet her sword was likewise layde,
And layes the soule to sleepe in quiet graue?
Before, behind, and round about him layes:
Which for this Realme found many goodly layes,
Aswell in curious instruments, as cunning layes.
Their daintie layes and dulcet melody,
Now making layes of loue and louers paine,
Straight he vpstarted from the loathed layes,
The fift Armeddan, skild in louely layes;
He him preuenting, layes on earth along,
Layes of sweete loue and youthes delightfull heat:
His layes, his loues, his lookes she did them all despize.
Which to thee flocke, to heare thy louely layes;
Pardon thy shepheard, mongst so many layes,
She set beside, laying his head disarm'd
Thither resorts, and laying his sad darts
And on his collar laying puissant hand,
Or helpe himselfe, and laying thwart her horse,
And vnawares vpon her laying hold,
Chasing, and laying on them heauy lode,
And laying both his hands vpon his glaue,
He with him closd, and laying mightie hold
And laying hand vpon his wrathfull blade,
And laying yet a fresh with courage stout
Lo vnderneath her scornefull feete, was layne
For many corses, like a great Lay-stall
Like loathsome lazars, by the hedges lay.
Doe meete together on the watry lea,
There was the Liffy rolling downe the lea,
Her words preuaild: And then the learned leach
To fetch a Leach, the which had great insight
For Tryphon of sea gods the soueraine leach is hight.
So well that Leach did hearke to her request,
That he no worke at all left for the leach:
More need of leach-craft hath your Damozell,
Where many skilfull leaches him abide,
Aueugles sonne there in the leaches cure,
And to him said, If any leaches skill,
In leaches craft, by great Appolloes lore,
What medicine can any Leaches art
And thence Apollo King of Leaches brought.
For by no art, nor any leaches might
For he right well in Leaches craft was seene,
Which to recure, no skill of Leaches art
In hand of leachour vylde.
The loathed leachour. But the Dame halfe ded
But that old leachour, which with bold assault
The heauy plague, that for such leachours is prepard.
And like to lead the labyrinth about;
Thence lead her forth, about her dauncing round,
To wander, where wilde fortune would me lead,
Both feet and face one way are wont to lead.
Yet ceasest not thy wearie soles to lead,
To lead aright, that he should neuer fall
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
And euer with slow pace the knight did lead,
As lump of lead, and made darke clouds appeare;
The day that first doth lead the yeare around;
Which thee to endlesse bale captiued lead.
That streight did lead to Plutoes griesly raine:
With that his hand, more sad then lomp of lead,
Sithence I loathed haue my life to lead,
And an huge hoste into Northumber lead,
Halfe of thy dayes doest lead in horrour hideous.
Some headed with sad lead, some with pure gold;
That they which lead him, soone enforced beene
Then vp he rose like heauie lumpe of lead,
his dayes in dole doth lead.
Death is to him, that wretched life doth lead,
In which he long time afterwards did lead
That glorious spoyle of beautie with me lead,
Therefore me thither lead. No more he spake,
And now they lead him thence, of all forsaken,
As for to lead your selfe vnto your owne decay?
Then lead that shamefull life, vnworthy of a Knight.
But most the former villaine, which did lead
Which Shepheards lead, without debate or bitter strife.
Of life, which here in lowlinesse ye lead,
This simple sort of life, that shepheards lead,
And Calidore should lead the ring, as hee
That he should lead the daunce, as was his fashion;
Which with those gentle shepherds here I wont to lead.
To see him leade that Beast in bondage strong,
But whenas Morpheus had with leaden mace
For thy, he thrild thee with a leaden dart,
And afterwards them to his Dame he leades,
Here leadest in this goodly merry make,
Is not from hence the way, that leadeth right
With footing worne, and leading inward farre:
Me leading, in a secret corner layd,
She graunted, & them leading forth, the same did shew.
Now leading him into a secret shade
She hath the leading of a Martiall
Leading his friend away, full sorie to his vew.
Where they were leading Marinell away,
And leading th'euer-burning lampe astray,
Who streight her leading with meete maiestie
And a lewd foole her leading thorough dry and wet.
Leading a life so free and fortunate,
That neuer leads the traueiler astray,
That done, he leads him to the highest Mount;
Which loue he red to be, that leads each liuing kind.
Whereon nor fruit, nor leafe was euer seene,
And tremble like a leafe of Aspin greene,
Each trembling leafe, and whistling wind they heare,
But direfull deadly blacke both leafe and bloom,
Of mortall life the leafe, the bud, the flowre,
Both leafe and fruit, both too vntimely shed,
And languish as the leafe falne from the tree,
And euery leafe, that shaketh with the least
And gins to spread his leafe before the faire sunshine.
From knitting league with him, I you aread;
Which to confirme, and fast to bind their league,
Our selues in league of vowed loue we knit:
A friendly league of loue perpetuall
And fifty sisters water in leake vessels draw.
Yet is the bottle leake, and bag so torne,
His bodie leane and meagre as a rake,
Was wan and leane, that all her teeth arew,
Whereon she leaned euer, as befell:
And leaning on his elbow, these few wordes let fly.
Did lightly leape, where he them bound did see,
For the large leape, which Debon did compell
Feeling her leape out of her loathed nest,
In minde to leape into the mighty maine,
Did leape to her, as doth an eger hound
Her hart did leape, and all her hart-strings tremble,
To leape into the same after our liues end.
And wrath, he to him leaped furiously,
Lightly she leaped, as a wight forlore,
Like a fell Lyon leaped to him light,
Leapes forth into the floud, and there assaies
Leaping like wanton kids in pleasant Spring.
And lightly leaping from so monstrous maine,
The knight then lightly leaping to the pray,
Gan burne in filthy lust, and leaping light,
But Guyon lightly to him leaping, stayd
Vpon him lightly leaping without heed,
But the stout Damzell to him leaping light,
But tlo him leaping, len him such a knocke,
Like a wyld Gote, leaping from hill to hill,
And leaping to him light, would haue vnlast
And to him leaping, vengeance thought to take
He to him leapt, and that same enuious gage
But ground he gaue, and lightly leapt areare:
Into the same she leapt, and with the ore
Lightly Cambello leapt downe from his steed,
Into the floud: streight leapt the Carle vnblest,
But he was well aware, and leapt before his fall.
She lightly to him leapt, and in his necke
By strong enchauntments and blacke Magicke leare,
Thereto she learned was in Magicke leare,
He was invulnerable made by Magicke leare.
She turnd her selfe backe to her wicked leares
Late learnd what harme to hastie trust ensu'th,
And learnd her discipline of faith and veritie.
That lou'd a Bull, and learnd a beast to bee;
Hast learn'd to loue, let no whit thee dismay
So whylome learnd that mighty Iewish swaine,
Who hath not learnd him selfe first to subdew:
Or noursle vp in lore of learn'd Philosophy.
Or learn'd the art to please, I doe not fynd.
I from thenceforth haue learn'd to loue more deare
Had euer learn'd to loue the lowly things,
Vpon his foe, and his new force to learne;
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
Then sighing soft, I learne that litle sweet
Nor too much to prouoke; for he would learne
And learne from pleasures poyson to abstaine:
A harder lesson, to learne Continence
The warlike minds, to learne her goodly lore,
That it shall make him shake, and shortly learne to fall.
For till thou tidings learne, what her betide,
But well I weene, ye first desire to learne,
The mighty Mars, to learne his wanton playes:
A read thou Squire, that I the man may learne,
But when they could not learne it by no wize,
My hard mishaps, that ye may learne to shonne;
Ne stayed further newes thereof to learne,
They all doe learne to play the Paramours;
Who thither with her came, to learne and see
And learne to loue, by learning louers paines to rew.
And inly troubled was, the truth to learne.
And greatly it desir'd of her to learne,
And prayd the place of her abode to learne.
Now brought to this? By this now may ye learne,
I may beare armes, and learne to vse them right;
His name (quoth he) if that thou list to learne,
Ne by inquirie learne, nor ghesse by ayme.
First learne your outward sences to refraine
Drew neare, that he the truth of all by him mote learne.
In hope there newes to learne, how they mote best assay.
To blazon broad emongst her learned throng:
And learned had to loue with secret lookes,
Her words preuaild: And then the learned leach
Of whom he learned had in secret wise
His mortall life he learned had to frame
On which the thrise three learned Ladies play
Now O thou sacred Muse, most learned Dame,
Such homage till that instant neuer learned hee.
For well of yore he learned had to ride,
His learned daughters would to me report,
Exceld at Athens all the learned preace,
Ne like in grace, ne like in learned skill;
May learned be by cyphers, or by Magicke might.
To weet, the learned Merlin, well could tell,
Or other learned meanes could haue redrest
She learned had th'estate of Arthegall,
(This Liagore whylome had learned skill
As he had long bene learned to obay;
Yet neuer learned he such seruice, till that day.
For all that art he learned had of yore.
Which well she red out of the learned line,
The learned louer lost no time nor tyde,
Sith powre of hand, nor skill of learned brest,
Thereto she learned was in Magicke leare,
As she had learned readily by rote.
Of him, who goodly learned had of yore
My heart was launcht, and learned to haue loued,
So many learned impes, that shoote abrode,
With many a gentle Muse, and many a learned wit.
And Nemertea learned well to rule her lust.
That learned Ptolomaee his hight did take,
Ne euer saw faire guize, ne learned good,
Not so the Prince: for his well learned speare
To loue my selfe I learned had in schoole.
As if he learned had obedience long,
Ne spareth he most learned wits to rate,
That was the learnedst Ladie in her dayes,
and learnes her wise beheast.
He makes him Squire, and of him learnes
That of her heauenly learning he might taste,
Learning his ship from those white rocks to saue,
Then shine in learning, more then euer did
And learne to loue, by learning louers paines to rew.
And there the keeping haue of learnings threasures,
But that false Pilgrim, which that leasing told,
For he loathd leasing, and base flattery,
And all that fained is, as leasings, tales, and lies.
Leasings, backbytings, and vaine-glorious crakes,
Whom she with leasings lewdly did miscall,
And cluster thicke vnto his leasings vaine,
And others worth with leasings doest deface,
And faynes to weaue false tales and leasings bad,
Least suddaine mischiefe ye too rash prouoke:
Least to you hap, that happened to me heare,
Affraid, least to themselues the like mishappen might.
Least thou of her beleeue too lightly blame,
Least so great good, as he for her had wrought,
That him againe lou'd in the least degree:
And widowes ayd, least they should be vndone:
And to my foe betrayd, when least I feared ill.
That of the world least part to vs is red:
Least his long way his aged limbes should tire:
Yet feared least his boldnesse should offend,
Least by her presence daunger mote befall.
But if she had her least helpe to thee lent,
And staynd their prayses with thy least good part;
Least worse betide thee by some later chaunce.
Least thy foolhardize worke thy sad confusion.
For feare least Force or Fraud should vnaware
Least thou perhaps hereafter wish, and be withstood.
Honour is least, where oddes appeareth most.
The least of which was match for any knight.
But to delay the heat, least by mischaunce
Or th'Authour selfe could not at least attend
Least that his Lord they should behind inuade;
He doubted, least it were some magicall
Least we vnweeting hap to be fordonne:
But liuing art may not least part expresse,
For feare least her vnwares she should abrayd,
Least that too farre ye haue your sorrow sought:
Aye me, how much I feare, least loue it bee;
That when old Glauce saw, for feare least blame
Least that it should her turne to foule repriefe,
Least backe againe the kingdome he from them should beare.
Least afterwards it be too late to take thy flight.
Least his too haughtie hardines might reare
Least they their finnes should bruze, and surbate sore
At least eternall meede shall you abide.
And out of sight escaped at the least;
Ah God, what other could he do at least,
Least that his wound were inly well not healed,
Least he like one of them him selfe disguize,
And euery leafe, that shaketh with the least
Least his fraile senses were emperisht quight,
Much feared he, least ought did ill betide
Least worse on sea then vs on land befell.
Which speaking token sheweth at the least
Right sore I feare, least with vnworthy blames
That least auantage mote to him afford,
Least saluage beastes her person haue despoyld:
